summary.long: 2 Samuel is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: After the death of Saul, David returned from defeating the Amalekites and he stayed at Ziklag two days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day, a man came from the camp from being with Saul, with his clothes torn and with dirt on his head. When he came to David, he fell to the ground and bowed down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “Where did you come from?” He said to him, “I have escaped from the camp of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to him, “How did things go? Please tell me.” He answered, “When the army fled from the battle, and many of the people fell; also, Saul and Jonathan his son died.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David asked the young man who was reporting to him, “How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan died?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young man who was reporting to him said, “I merely happened to be on Mount Gilboa. Here Saul was leaning on his spear, and look, the chariots and the horsemen were getting close to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he turned around and saw me, he called to me, and I said, ‘Here I am.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to me, ‘Who are you?’ And I said to him, ‘I am an Amalekite.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to me, ‘Please stand over me and kill me, for convulsions have seized me, even though my life is still in me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I stood over him and killed him, for I knew that he could not live after his falling; I took the crown that was on his head and the bracelet which was on his arm; and here, I have brought them to my lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David grabbed at his clothes and tore them, as did all of the men who were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they mourned and wept and fasted over Saul and Jonathan his son until the evening, as well as over the people of Yahweh and over the house of Israel because they had fallen by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to the young man who was reporting to him, “Where are you from?” And he said, “I am the son of an alien man. I am an Amalekite.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “How is it that you were not afraid to stretch out your hand to destroy Yahweh’s anointed one?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David called to one of the young men and said to him, “Come near; strike him.” So he struck him down and he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “Your blood is on your head, for your mouth has testified against you by saying, ‘I killed Yahweh’s anointed one!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sang this funeral song over Saul and over Jonathan his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he ordered “The Bow” to be taught to the children of Judah. Look, it is written on the scroll of Jashar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The glory of Israel is on your high places; how the mighty have fallen!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not tell it in Gath; do not proclaim it in the streets of Ashkelon,
    lest the daughters of the Philistines rejoice,
    lest the daughters of the uncircumcised exult.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O mountains of Gilboa, let there be no dew or rain upon you
    or on the fields of grain for offerings,
    for there the small shield of the mighty was defiled,
    the small shield of Saul was not anointed with oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From the blood of the slain, from the fat of the mighty,
    the bow of Jonathan did not turn back,
    and the sword of Saul did not return without effect.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul and Jonathan were beloved and pleasant in their lives
    and were not separated in their death.
    They were swifter than eagles, stronger than lions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O daughters of Israel, weep over Saul,
    the one who clothed you with crimson,
    the one who adorned your clothing with golden ornaments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How the mighty have fallen in the midst of the battle;
    Jonathan lies slain on your high places.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: How the mighty have fallen and the weapons of warfare perished.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened after this that David inquired of Yahweh, saying, “Shall I go up into one of the cities of Judah?” And Yahweh said to him, “Go up.” David asked, “Where shall I go up?” And he said, “To Hebron.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went up there along with his two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, David brought up his men who were with him, each with his household, and they settled in the towns of Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the men of Judah came, and they anointed David there as king over the house of Judah, and they told David, “The men of Jabesh-Gilead buried Saul.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent messengers to the men of Jabesh-Gilead and said to them, “May you be blessed by Yahweh because you did this loyal love with your lord, with Saul, and you buried him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now may Yahweh show loyal love and faithfulness with you. I will also show the good with you that you have done in this matter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, let your hands be strong and be valiant, for your lord Saul is dead, and the house of Judah has anointed me as king over them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abner the son of Ner, the commander of Saul’s army, had taken Ish-Bosheth the son of Saul and brought him over to Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made him king over Gilead, over the Ashurites, over Jezreel, over Ephraim, over Benjamin, and over Israel, all of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ish-Bosheth the son of Saul was forty years old when he became king over Israel and he reigned two years; however, the house of Judah followed David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The number of days that David was king over Hebron, over the house of Judah, was seven years and six months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner the son of Ner and the servants of Ish-Bosheth the son of Saul went out from Mahanaim to Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab the son of Zeruiah and the servants of David went out, and they met at the pool of Gibeon. The one group sat on one side of the pool, and the other sat on the other side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner said to Joab, “Let the young men come up and fight in our presence.” And Joab said, “Let them come up.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they came forward and passed by in number: twelve for Benjamin and for Ish-Bosheth the son of Saul, and twelve from the servants of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then each seized his opponent by the head and each thrust his sword in the side of his opponent, so they fell together. So they called the name of that place Helkath Hazzurim, which is in Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the battle became increasingly fierce on that day, and Abner and the men of Israel were defeated before the servants of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The three sons of Zeruiah were there, Joab and Abishai and Asahel. Now Asahel was swift with his feet as one of the gazelles which is in the open field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Asahel pursued Abner, and he did not turn aside to the right or to the left from going after Abner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner turned around and said, “Are you this Asahel?” And he said, “Yes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner said to him, “Turn aside to your right or to your left; seize for yourself one of the young men, and take his belongings for yourself.” But Asahel was not willing to turn aside from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abner said to Asahel once again, “For your own sake, turn aside from following me. Why should I strike you down to the ground? How could I show my face to Joab your brother?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he refused to turn away, so Abner struck him in the stomach with the butt of the spear, and the spear went out of his back. He fell there and he died on the spot. Then all who came to the place where Asahel fell and died just stood there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab and Abishai pursued Abner when the sun went down. And they came to the hill country of Ammah, which is before Giah on the way to the wilderness of Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Benjamin rallied after Abner, and they became as one fighting group and stood on the top of a certain hill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abner called to Joab and said, “Will the sword devour forever? Do you not know that there will be bitterness in the end? How long will you not tell the people to turn away from pursuing their brothers?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said, “As God lives, for if you had not spoken, the people would surely have gone up in the morning, each one of them from following after his brother.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab blew on the trumpet and all the people stopped, and they no longer pursued after Israel, and they did not fight with them again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abner and his men went through the Arabah all that night, and they crossed over the Jordan. They went all the forenoon and came to Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Joab returned from pursuing Abner, he gathered all the people; nineteen of the servants of David were missing along with Asahel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servants of David had killed some of the Benjaminites among the men of Abner; three hundred and sixty men had died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they picked up Asahel and buried him in the grave of his father, which was at Bethlehem. Joab and his men went all that night arriving in Hebron at first light.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The battle was prolonged between the house of Saul and the house of David, but David was growing stronger and stronger while the house of Saul was becoming weaker and weaker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And sons were born to David in Hebron; his firstborn was Amnon by Ahinoam from Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His second was Kileab by Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite; the third was Absalom the son of Maacah, who was the daughter of Talmai the king of Geshur.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fourth was Adonijah the son of Haggith; the fifth was Shephatiah the son of Abital.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sixth was Ithream by Eglah the wife of David. These were born to David in Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the war between the house of Saul and the house of David was continuing, Abner was strengthening himself in the house of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul had had a concubine, and her name was Rizpah the daughter of Aiah. Then Ish-Bosheth said to Abner, “Why did you have sex with my father’s concubine?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner became very angry at the words of Ish-Bosheth, and he said, “Am I the head of a dog which is for Judah today? Do I not continue to show loyal love with the house of Saul your father, to his brothers, and to his friends? I have not let you fall into the hands of David, yet you have accused me of sin with this woman today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thus may God punish Abner, if I do not accomplish what Yahweh has sworn to David;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: specifically, to transfer the kingdom from the house of Saul and to establish the throne of David over Israel and over Judah from Dan to Beersheba!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Ish-Bosheth was no longer able to answer Abner because he feared him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner sent messengers to David where he was, saying, “To whom does the land belong? Make your covenant with me! Look, my hand is with you to bring all of Israel over to you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Good. I will make a covenant with you. I am asking only one thing from you: You shall not see my face unless you bring Michal the daughter of Saul when you come to see me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sent messengers to Ish-Bosheth the son of Saul, saying, “Give me my wife Michal whom I betrothed to myself for a hundred foreskins of the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ish-Bosheth sent and took her from her husband, from Paltiel the son of Laish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But her husband went with her, weeping all along after her as far as Bahurim. Then Abner said to him, “Go and return.” So he returned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word of Abner came to the elders of Israel, saying, “For quite some time you were seeking David as king over you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, bring it about, because Yahweh had said to David, “Through the hand of David my servant I am about to save my people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from the hand of all their enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner also spoke privately to Benjamin. Abner also went to speak to David in Hebron, all that was good in the eyes of Israel and in the eyes of all the house of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abner came to David in Hebron and with him were twenty men. David had prepared a feast for Abner and for the men who were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Abner said to David, “Let me get up and go and gather all of Israel to my lord the king, that they may make a covenant with you so you can reign over all which your soul desires.” So David dismissed Abner, and he left in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And look, the servants of David and Joab came from the raid, and they brought much plunder with them. But Abner was not with David at Hebron, for he had dismissed him, and he had gone in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab and all the army that was with him came, they told Joab, “Abner the son of Ner came to the king, and he sent him away, and he left in peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab came to the king and said, “What have you done? Abner came here to you? Why have you dismissed him that he actually went away?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know that Abner the son of Ner came to deceive you. He came to learn about your going out and coming in and to know all which you are doing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab went out from David, and he sent messengers after Abner, and they brought him back from Bor Hasirah, but David did not know it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab took him aside to the middle of the gate to speak with him in private. Then he struck him in the stomach there and he died, for he had shed the blood of Asahel his brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard this afterwards, he said: “I and my kingdom are innocent before Yahweh forever for the blood of Abner the son of Ner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the blood come down on the head of Joab and all the house of his father. May the house of Joab never lack one with a bodily discharge or one with leprosy or one who grasps the distaff or one who falls by the sword or one who is lacking food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab and Abishai, his brother, killed Abner because he had killed Asahel, their brother, at Gibeon in the battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Joab and to all the people who were with him, “Tear your clothing and put on sackcloth and mourn before Abner.” Now King David was following after the bier.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they buried Abner at Hebron. And the king lifted up his voice and wept at the grave of Abner, and all the people wept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king sang a lament for Abner and said, “Should Abner have died the death of a fool?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your hands were not tied and your feet were not in contact with bronze fetters. You have fallen as one who falls before sons of wickedness.” Then all the people wept over him again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people came to give David food. Still on that day, David swore, “May God punish me if I taste food or anything before the sun goes down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people noticed, and it was good in their eyes, as everything that the king did was good in the eyes of all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people and all of Israel realized on that day that the king had not desired to kill Abner the son of Ner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to his servants, “Did you not realize that a prince and a great man has fallen today in Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am weak today even though anointed king, and these men, the sons of Zeruiah, are crueler than I am. May Yahweh pay them back for doing wickedness according to their own wickedness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the son of Saul heard that Abner had died in Hebron, his courage failed and all of Israel was horrified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two of the men, commanders of the raiding bands, were for the son of Saul. The name of one was Baanah, and the name of the other was Recab, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite from the descendants of Benjamin; also, Beeroth was regarded as belonging to Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Beerothites fled to Gittaim, and they are resident aliens there until this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now Jonathan the son of Saul had a son who was crippled in the feet. He was five years old when the message of Saul and Jonathan came from Jezreel, and his nurse had picked him up and fled. It happened that as she was hurrying away to flee, he fell and became crippled. His name was Mephibosheth.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, Recab and Baanah, set out, they came at the heat of the day to the house of Ish-Bosheth while he was taking a noontime rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came as far as the middle of the house as if takers of wheat, and they struck him in the stomach. Then Recab and Baanah his brother escaped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had come into the house, he was lying on his couch in his bedchamber, and they attacked him and killed him. Then they beheaded him, and they took his head and went on the way of the Arabah all night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought the head of Ish-Bosheth to David at Hebron, and they said to the king, “Here is the head of Ish-Bosheth, the son of Saul your enemy, who sought your life. Yahweh has given to my lord the king vengeance this day on Saul and on his offspring.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David answered Recab and Baanah his brother, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, and he said to them, “As Yahweh lives, who redeemed my soul from all trouble,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when the one who told me, “Look, Saul is dead,” thought that he was bringing good news, I seized him and killed him at Ziklag, which was as my giving the news back to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How much more when wicked men kill a righteous man in his house, on his bed! So then, shall I not seek his lifeblood from your hand, so that I may destroy you from the earth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David commanded the young men, and they killed them, and they cut off their hands and their feet, and they hung them at the pool at Hebron, but the head of Ish-Bosheth they took and buried in the grave of Abner at Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron, and they said, “Here we are, we are your flesh and blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For some time, when Saul was king over us, you were leading Israel in and out. Yahweh had said to you, ‘You shall be the shepherd of my people Israel, and you will be the leader over Israel.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron, and King David made a covenant with them at Hebron in the presence of Yahweh; then they anointed David as king over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was thirty years old when he began to reign; he reigned forty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He reigned over Judah at Hebron for seven years and six months; and he reigned over all Israel and Judah at Jerusalem for thirty-three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and his men went to Jerusalem, to the Jebusites, the inhabitants of the land. They said to David, “You will not come here, for even the blind and the lame can turn you back, saying, ‘David cannot come here.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David captured the fortress of Zion, the city of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had said, “On that day when we attack the Jebusites, one must attack the lame and the blind, those who hate the soul of David, by means of the water supply.” For thus the blind and the lame would say, “He cannot come into the house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David occupied the fortress and called it the city of David. And David built all around it from the Millo and inward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David continued growing stronger and stronger, and Yahweh the God of hosts was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hiram, the king of Tyre, sent messengers to David, along with cedar trees and craftsmen skilled in wood and in stone masonry, and they built a house for David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David realized that Yahweh had established him as king over Israel and that he had exalted his kingdom because of his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took more concubines and wives from Jerusalem after he came from Hebron, and more sons and daughters were born to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of the ones born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua and Shobab and Nathan and Solomon;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ibhar and Elishua and Nepheg and Japhia;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elishama and Eliada and Eliphelet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Philistines heard that they had anointed David as king over Israel, all the Philistines went up to seek David, but David heard and went down to the stronghold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Philistines had come, and they spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And David inquired of Yahweh, saying, “Shall I go up to the Philistines? Will you give them into my hands?” Yahweh said to David, “Go up, for I will certainly give the Philistines into your hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David came to Baal Perazim and defeated them there; and David said, “Yahweh has burst through my enemies before me like the bursting of water.” Therefore he called the name of that place Baal Perazim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They had left their idols there, so David and his men carried them away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once again the Philistines came up and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David inquired of Yahweh, but he said, “You shall not go up. Rather, go around to their rear and come to them from opposite the balsam trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And it shall be that when you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, then pay attention, for then Yahweh has gone out before you to strike down the army of the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David did thus, just as Yahweh had commanded him, and he struck down the Philistines from Geba all the way to Gezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David again gathered all the chosen men in Israel, thirty thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David got up and went and all the people who were with him, from Baale-judah to bring up from there the ark of God which is called the name, the name of Yahweh of hosts, upon which the cherubim sit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They loaded the ark of God on a new utility cart, and they carried it from the house of Abinadab, which was on the hill. Now Uzza and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, were driving the new utility cart along.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they brought it out from the house of Abinadab, which was on the hill with the ark of God, and Ahio was going before the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David and all the house of Israel were dancing before Yahweh, with all kinds of musical instruments made from ash trees, and with zithers, harps, tambourines, sistrums, and cymbals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to the threshing floor of Nakon, Uzza reached out to the ark of God and took hold of it, because the oxen had stumbled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the anger of Yahweh was kindled against Uzza, and God struck him down there because of the indiscretion, and he died there beside the ark of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was angry because Yahweh had burst out against Uzza, and he called that place Perez-Uzza until this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David feared Yahweh on that day and said, “How can the ark of Yahweh come to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, David was not willing to bring the ark of Yahweh to himself, to the city of David, so David caused it to turn to the house of Obed-Edom the Gittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the ark of Yahweh remained in the house of Obed-Edom the Gittite for three months, and Yahweh blessed Obed-Edom and all his household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was told to King David, “Yahweh has blessed the household of Obed-Edom and all that is his because of the ark of God.” So David went and brought up the ark of God from the house of Obed-Edom to the city of David with jubilation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened that when the carriers of the ark of Yahweh had marched six steps that he sacrificed an ox and a fatling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David was dancing with all his might before Yahweh, and David was wearing a linen ephod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and all the house of Israel were bringing up the ark of Yahweh with shouts of joyful acclaim and with the sound of the trumpet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened that when the ark of Yahweh came into the city of David, Michal the daughter of Saul looked down through the window and saw King David leaping and dancing before Yahweh, and she despised him in her heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought the ark of Yahweh and set it in its place in the middle of the tent which David had pitched for it. Then David offered up burnt offerings and fellowship offerings in the presence of Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David had finished from the sacrificing of the burnt offerings and the fellowship offerings, he blessed the people in the name of Yahweh of hosts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he distributed to all the people, to all the multitude of Israel, from man to woman, to each: one ring-shaped piece of bread, one cake of dates, and one cake of raisins; and all the people went each to his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David returned to bless his household, Michal the daughter of Saul came out to meet David. She said, “How the king of Israel honored himself today by uncovering himself before the eyes of the maids of his servants, as the total exposure of a worthless one.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David said to Michal, “In the presence of Yahweh who chose me over your father and over his household, to appoint me as leader over the people of Yahweh, over Israel, I have celebrated before Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will demean myself again more than this, and I will be abased in my eyes, but with the maids whom you mentioned, with them I will be honored.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So for Michal the daughter of Saul, she had no child until the day of her death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened that the king settled in his house. (Now Yahweh had given rest to him from all his enemies all around.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the king said to Nathan the prophet, “Look, please, I am living in a house of cedar, but the ark of God is staying in the middle of the tent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan said to the king, “Go and do all that is in your heart, for Yahweh is with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But it happened that night, the word of Yahweh came to Nathan, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and tell my servant David, ‘Thus says Yahweh: “Are you the one to build for me a house for my dwelling?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I have not dwelt in a house from the day I brought up the Israelites from Egypt until this day; rather, I was going about in a tent and in a tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In all of my going about among all the Israelites, did I speak a word with one of the tribes of Israel whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel, saying, ‘Why did you not build me a cedar house?’”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, thus you shall say to my servant David, ‘Thus says Yahweh of hosts, “I took you from the pasture from following the sheep to be a leader over my people, over Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I have been with you everywhere you went. I have cut off all of your enemies from in front of you, and I will make a great name for you, as the name of the great ones who are on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make a place for my people Israel, and I will plant them so that they can dwell in their own place. They will not tremble any longer, and the children of wickedness will not afflict them again, as in the former days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the manner that I appointed judges over my people Israel, I will give you rest from all your enemies. And Yahweh declares to you that Yahweh will build a house for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When your days are full and you lie down with your ancestors, I will raise up your offspring after you who will go out from your body, and I will establish his kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will build a house for my name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will be a father to him, and he will be a son for me, whom I will punish when he does wrong, with a rod of men and with blows of the human beings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But my loyal love shall not depart from him as I took it from Saul, whom I removed from before you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your house and your kingdom shall endure forever before you; your throne shall be established forever.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: According to all these words and according to all this vision, this Nathan spoke to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David went and sat before Yahweh and said, “Who am I, my lord Yahweh, and what is my house that you have brought me up to this place?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Still, this was insignificant in your eyes, my lord Yahweh, and also you have spoken about the house of your servant from afar, and this may be the teaching of humans, my lord Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What more can David say to you? You know your servant, my lord Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of your word and according to your heart, you have done all of this great thing, in order to let your servant know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore you are great, my lord Yahweh, for there is no one like you, and there is no god except you, in all that we have heard with our ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who is like your people, like Israel? Israel is the one nation on earth whose God led them, in order to redeem a people for himself, and to make a name for himself, and to do for you the great and awesome things for your land in the presence of your people whom he redeemed for himself from Egypt, from the nations and their gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have established your people Israel for yourself as a people forever, and you, O Yahweh, have become their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, Yahweh God, the word that you have spoken concerning your servant and concerning his house, confirm it forever, and do just as you have promised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your name shall be great forever, and they will say, ‘Yahweh of hosts is God over Israel’; and the house of your servant David shall be established before you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you, O Yahweh of hosts, are God of Israel! You have revealed to the ear of your servant, ‘I will build a house for you’; therefore your servant has found courage to pray this prayer to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, my Lord Yahweh, you alone are God, and your words are true. You have promised this good to your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, be content and bless the house of your servant to be forever in your presence, for you, my Lord Yahweh, have spoken, and because of your blessing, may the house of your servant be blessed forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened afterwards that David attacked the Philistines and subdued them, and he took Metheg Ammah from the hands of the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he defeated Moab, he measured them with the cord, making them lie on the ground. He measured two cords to kill and the third cord to let live. So Moab became servants of David, bringing tribute.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David struck down Hadadezer the son of Rehob, king of Zobah, when he went to restore his monument at the Euphrates River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David captured from him one thousand and seven hundred horsemen and twenty thousand foot soldiers. David hamstrung all the chariot horses, but from them he spared a hundred chariot horses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Aram of Damascus came to help Hadadezer, the king of Zobah, David killed twenty-two thousand men of Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David placed garrisons in Aram of Damascus, so Aram became servants of David, bringing tribute. Yahweh protected David everywhere he went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took the small round gold shields which had belonged to the servants of Hadadezer, and he brought them to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Betah and from Berothai, the towns of Hadadezer, King David took very many bronze items.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Toi, the king of Hamath, heard that David had defeated all the army of Hadadezer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Toi sent Joram his son to King David to greet him and to congratulate him because he had fought against Hadadezer and defeated him; for Hadadezer had often been at war with Toi. He brought with him objects of silver and objects of gold and objects of bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David dedicated them also to Yahweh along with the silver and the gold that he had dedicated from all of the nations which he had subdued;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Aram and from Moab and from the Ammonites and from the Philistines and from Amalek and from the plunder of Hadadezer the son of Rehob, the king of Zobah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David made a name for himself when he returned from defeating Aram in the Valley of Salt, eighteen thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put garrisons in Edom; all over Edom he put garrisons, and all of Edom became servants of David. Yahweh protected David wherever he went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David reigned over all of Israel, and he was administering justice and righteousness for all his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab the son of Zeruiah was over the army, and Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was secretary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zadok the son of Ahitub and Ahimelech the son of Abiathar were priests and Seraiah was scribe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the Kerethites and the Pelethites, and the sons of David were priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said, “Is there still anyone who is left for the house of Saul that I may show loyal love to him for the sake of Jonathan?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Saul’s household had a servant whose name was Ziba, so they summoned him to David, and the king asked him, “Are you Ziba?” He said, “At your service!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said, “But is there still anyone of Saul’s household that I may show the loyal love of God with him?” And Ziba said to the king, “There is still a son of Jonathan who is lame in the feet.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to him, “Where is he?” And Ziba said to the king, “He is here in the house of Makir the son of Ammiel in Lo Debar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King David sent and brought him from the house of Makir the son of Ammiel from Lo Debar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Mephibosheth the son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, came to David. And he fell on his face and did obeisance. David said, “Mephibosheth,” and he said, “I am ready to serve you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to him, “Don’t be afraid, for I will certainly show loyal love to you for the sake of Jonathan your father, and I will restore to you all the lands of Saul your father. And you shall always eat food at my table.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he did obeisance and said, “What is your servant that you have paid attention to the dead dog like me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David summoned Ziba the servant of Saul and said to him, “All that was Saul’s and all his household I have given to the son of your master.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall till the land for him, you and your sons and your servants; you shall bring in the produce and it shall be food for the son of your master that he may eat. But Mephibosheth the son of your master may always eat food at my table.” (Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty slaves.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ziba said to the king, “According to all that my master the king commands his servant, so your servant will do.” So Mephibosheth was eating at his table as one of the sons of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Mephibosheth had a young son whose name was Micah, and all of the dwelling of the household of Ziba became servants for Mephibosheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Mephibosheth was living in Jerusalem, because he was continually eating at the table of the king, even though he was lame in both of his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterwards the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanun ruled in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said, “I will show loyal love with Hanun, the son of Nahash, as his father showed loyal love with me.” So David sent to console him concerning his father, by the hand of his servants. And the servants of David came to the land of the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the commanders of the Ammonites said to Hanun their master, “In your opinion, is David honoring your father because he has sent condolences to you? Is it not in order to search the city, to spy it out, and to overthrow it that David sent his servants to you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hanun took the servants of David, and he shaved off half of their beards and cut their garments off in the middle up to their buttocks, then sent them away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they told David, he sent to meet them, for the men were greatly ashamed. And the king said, “Remain in Jericho until your beards have grown, and then you can return.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Ammonites saw that they had become odious to David, the Ammonites sent word and hired Aram Beth-Rehob and Aram-Zobah, twenty thousand infantry; and they also hired the king of Maacah, a thousand men, and the men of Tob, twelve thousand men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard, he sent Joab and all the army of mighty warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ammonites came out and drew up a battle formation at the entrance of the gate, but Aram-Zobah and Rehob and the men of Tob and Maacah were alone in the open field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab saw that the battle was to be fought on two fronts, he chose from all the members of the elite troops of Israel and lined them up for battle to meet Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the army he placed into the hand of his brother Abishai, who arranged them in battle lines to meet the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said, “If Aram is stronger than I am, you must become my deliverer; but if the Ammonites are too strong for you, then I will come to rescue you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be strong, and let us strengthen ourselves for the sake of the people and for the sake of the cities of our God. May Yahweh do what is good in his eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab and all the people who were with him moved forward into the battle against Aram, and they fled from before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Ammonites saw that Aram had fled, they fled from before Abishai and entered the city. Then Joab returned from fighting against the Ammonites and came to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Arameans saw that they were defeated before Israel, they gathered themselves together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hadadezer sent and brought out the Arameans who were beyond the Euphrates, and they came to Helam. Now Shobach, the commander of the army of Hadadezer, was at their head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was told, so he gathered all Israel and crossed over the Jordan and came to Helam. Aram arranged themselves in battle lines to meet David, and they fought with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Aram fled before Israel, and David killed from the Arameans seven hundred chariot teams and forty thousand horsemen. He struck down Shobach, the commander of his army, and he died there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the kings, the servants of Hadadezer, saw that he had been defeated before Israel, they made peace with Israel and served them, and Aram was afraid to help the Ammonites any longer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It came about in the spring, at the time kings go out, David sent Joab and his servants with him and all of Israel. They ravaged all of the Ammonites and besieged Rabbah, but David was remaining in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened late one afternoon that David got up from his bed and walked about on the roof of the king’s house, and he saw a woman bathing on her roof. Now the woman was very beautiful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent and inquired about the woman, and someone said, “Is this not Bathsheba the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sent messengers and took her, and she came to him, and he slept with her. (Now she had been purifying herself from her uncleanness.) And she returned to her house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman became pregnant, and she sent and told David, and she said, “I am pregnant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent to Joab, “Send Uriah the Hittite to me.” So Joab sent Uriah to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uriah came to him, and David asked how Joab and the army fared and how the war was going.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Uriah, “Go down to your house, and wash your feet.” So Uriah went out from the king’s house, and a gift from the king went out after him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Uriah slept at the entrance of the king’s house with all the servants of his master and did not go down to his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told David, “Uriah did not go down to his house.” David said to Uriah, “Are you not coming from a journey? Why did you not go down to your house?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uriah said to David, “The ark and Israel and Judah are living in the booths; and my lord Joab and the servants of my lord are camping on the surface of the open field; and I, shall I go to my house to eat and to drink and to sleep with my wife? By your life and the life of your soul, I surely will not do this thing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Uriah, “Remain here today, and tomorrow I will send you away.” So Uriah remained in Jerusalem on that day and the next.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David invited him, and he ate and drank in his presence so that he became drunk, and he went out in the evening to lie on his bed with the servants of his lord, but he did not go down to his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And it happened in the morning, David wrote a letter to Joab, and he sent it by the hand of Uriah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had written in the letter, “Put Uriah in the front, in the face of the fiercest fighting, then draw back from behind him so that he may be struck down and die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab was besieging the city, he put Uriah toward the place which he knew there were valiant warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of the city came out and fought with Joab. Some from the army from the servants of David fell; Uriah the Hittite also died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab sent and told David all of the news of the battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He instructed the messenger, saying, “As you are finishing to speak all the news of the battle to the king,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: if the anger of the king rises and he says to you, ‘Why did you go near the city to fight? Did you not know that they would shoot from atop the wall?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who killed Abimelech the son of Jerub-bosheth, if not a woman who threw an upper millstone on him from atop the wall and he died at Thebez? Why did you go near the wall?’ Then you shall say, ‘Your servant Uriah the Hittite also died.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the messenger left, and he came and told David all that Joab had sent him to say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messenger said to David, “Because the men overpowered us, the men came out to us in the field, but we forced them back to the entrance of the gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The archers shot at your servant from atop the wall, and some of the servants of the king died; your servant Uriah the Hittite also died.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to the messenger, “Thus you shall say to Joab, ‘Do not feel badly about this matter; now one and then another the sword will devour. Intensify your attack on the city and overthrow it.’” And he encouraged him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the wife of Uriah heard that Uriah her husband was dead, she mourned over her husband.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the mourning was over, David sent and brought her to his household, and she became his wife and bore him a son. But the thing which David had done was evil in the eyes of Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Yahweh sent Nathan to David, and he came to him and said, “Two men were in a certain city; one was rich and the other was poor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rich man had very many flocks and herds,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but the poor man had nothing except for one small ewe lamb which he had bought. He had nurtured her, and she grew up with him and with his children together. She used to eat from his morsel and drink from his cup, and she used to lie in his lap and became like a daughter for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And a visitor came to the rich man, but he was reluctant to take from his flocks or from his herds to prepare a meal for the traveler when he came to him. So he took the ewe lamb of the poor man and prepared it for the man who had come to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the anger of David was kindled against the man, and he said to Nathan, “As Yahweh lives, the man who has done this deserves to die!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He shall restore the ewe lamb fourfold because he has done this thing, and because he had no pity.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Nathan said to him, “You are the man! Thus says Yahweh the God of Israel: ‘I anointed you as king over Israel, and I delivered you from the hand of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I gave you the household of your master and the women of your master into your lap. I also gave you the house of Israel and Judah; if that had been too little, I would have added to you much more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why have you despised the word of Yahweh by doing evil in his eyes? Uriah the Hittite you have struck down with the sword, and his wife you have taken to yourself as wife! You have killed him with the sword of the Ammonites!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, a sword will not turn away from your house forever, because you have despised me and have taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your wife!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thus says Yahweh, ‘Look, I am going to raise up evil against you from within your house, and I will take your women before your eyes, and I will give them to your neighbor, and he shall sleep with your wives in broad daylight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Though you did this in secret, I will do this thing before all of Israel in broad daylight!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against Yahweh!” Nathan said to David, “Yahweh has also forgiven your sin; you shall not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But because you have utterly scorned Yahweh in this matter, the son born for you will certainly die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Nathan went to his house, and Yahweh struck the child that the wife of Uriah bore for David, and he became ill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David pleaded with God on behalf of the boy and David fasted. He went to spend the night and lay upon the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The elders of his household stood over him to lift him up from the ground, but he was not willing, and he did not eat any food with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened on the seventh day that the child died, and the servants of David were afraid to tell him that the child was dead, for they said, “Look, when the child was alive, we spoke to him, but he would not listen to our voice. How can we tell him, ‘The child is dead’? He may do something evil.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David saw that his servants were whispering together, he realized that the child was dead. Then David said to his servants, “Is the child dead?” And they said, “He is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David stood up from the ground and washed and anointed himself and changed his clothing. Then he went to the house of Yahweh and worshiped, and he went to his own house. He asked, so they served him food, and he ate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his servants said to him, “What is this thing that you have done? While the child was alive, you fasted and wept; now that the child has died, you get up and eat food!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “When the child was still alive, I fasted and I wept because I thought, ‘Who knows? Yahweh may have mercy on me that the child will live.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now he is dead. Why should I be fasting? Am I able to return him again? I am going to him, but he cannot return to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David consoled Bathsheba his wife, and he went to her and slept with her. She bore a son, and he called him Solomon, and Yahweh loved him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent word by the hand of Nathan the prophet, so he called him Jedidiah because of Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Joab fought against Rabbah of the Ammonites, and he captured the royal city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab sent messengers to David and said, “We have fought against Rabbah, and we captured the city of the waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, gather the remainder of the army and encamp against the city and capture it, lest I capture the city and my name be proclaimed over it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David gathered all of the army, and he went to Rabbah and fought against it and captured it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took the crown of their king from his head. (Now its weight was a talent of gold, and there was a precious stone in it and it was put on David’s head.) He brought out the plunder of the city in great abundance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also brought out the people who were in it and put them to the saws and to the iron picks and to the iron axes, and he sent them to the place of the brickmakers. Thus he used to do to all the cities of the Ammonites, and he and all of the army returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened afterwards that Absalom the son of David had a beautiful sister whose name was Tamar, and Amnon the son of David fell in love with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Amnon was so frustrated that he felt ill because of Tamar his sister, because she was a virgin, and it was too difficult in Amnon’s eyes to do anything with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Amnon had a friend whose name was Jonadab the son of Shimeah, the brother of David. (Now Jonadab was a very crafty man.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he said to him, “Why are you so sullen every morning, O son of the king? Will you not tell me?” And Amnon said to him, “I am in love with Tamar, the sister of my brother Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonadab said to him, “Lie down on your bed and appear ill. If your father comes to see you, you shall say to him, ‘Please let Tamar my sister come and give me food to eat, and let her prepare the food before my eyes, in order that I may see it and eat from her hand.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amnon lay down and pretended to be ill, and the king came to see him. Amnon said to the king, “Please let Tamar my sister come, and let her bake two cakes before my eyes that I may eat from her hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent to the house for Tamar, saying, “Please go to the house of Amnon your brother and prepare food for him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tamar went to the house of Amnon her brother. Now he was lying down, and she took the dough and kneaded it and made cakes before his eyes, and she baked the cakes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she took the pan and poured it out before him, but he refused to eat. Then Amnon said, “Let all the men go out from me.” So all the men went out from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Amnon said to Tamar, “Bring the food to the private room that I may eat from your hand.” So Tamar took the cakes which she had made and brought them to Amnon her brother in the private room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she brought them near to him to eat, he took hold of her and said to her, “Come, lie with me, my sister!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Tamar said to him, “No, my brother! Do not force me, for such a thing has not been done in Israel. Do not do this disgraceful thing!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for me, where should I take my disgrace? You will be as one of the fools in Israel. So please, speak to the king, for he will not withhold me from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he was not willing to listen to her voice. He was stronger than she, and he forced her and lay with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Amnon hated her very deeply, for the hatred with which he hated her was greater than the love with which he had loved her. So Amnon said to her, “Get up and go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said to him, “No, because this evil in sending me away is greater than the other you have done to me.” But he was not willing to listen to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he called his young man who was serving him and said, “Please send this woman from me to the outside, and bolt the door behind her!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there was a long-sleeved robe on her, for so they clothed the daughters of the king who were virgins, in robes. His servant put her outside, and he bolted the door behind her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tamar put ashes on her head, and she tore the long-sleeved robe which was on her. She put her hand on her head, and she went away, crying out as she went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom her brother said to her, “Was Amnon your brother with you? But now, my sister, be quiet; he is your brother. Do not take this matter to heart.” So Tamar remained a desolate woman in the house of Absalom her brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now King David heard all these things, and he became very angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom did not speak with Amnon either bad or good, for Absalom hated Amnon over the matter when he raped Tamar his sister.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About two full years later, Absalom’s shearers were in Baal Hazor, which is near Ephraim, and Absalom summoned all the sons of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom went to the king and said, “Look, here are your servant’s shearers; please let the king and his servants go with your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Absalom, “No my son, not all of us shall go, so that we not be a burden to you.” And he urged him, but he was not willing to go, but he blessed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Absalom said, “But will you not let Amnon my brother go with us?” And the king said to him, “Why should he go with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom pressed him, so he sent Amnon with him and all of the sons of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom commanded his servants, saying, “Please watch. At the moment the heart of Amnon is tipsy with wine, then I shall say to you, ‘Strike Amnon down,’ and you shall kill him! Don’t be afraid. Is it not I myself who has commanded you? Be courageous and be valiant!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Absalom’s servants did to Amnon just as Absalom commanded, and all the sons of the king got up, and each mounted his mule and fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were on the way, the message came to David, “Absalom has killed all the sons of the king, and not one of them was left.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king rose and tore his garments, and he lay on the ground, and all his servants standing by were tearing their garments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonadab the son of Shimeah, the brother of David, responded and said, “My lord should not think that all the young men, the sons of the king, are dead, because only Amnon is dead. Absalom was talking about it, as it was being determined from the day he raped Tamar his sister.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, let not my lord the king set his heart on this matter, thinking, ‘All the sons of the king are dead,’ for only Amnon alone is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Absalom fled, and the young man who was keeping watch lifted up his eyes and saw, and there were many people coming from the road behind him from the side of the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonadab said to the king, “Look, the sons of the king have come. According to the word of your servant, so it has come about.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he finished speaking, look, the sons of the king came and they lifted up their voice and wept. Also, the king and all his servants wept a very great weeping.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom fled and went to Talmai the son of Ammihur, the king of Geshur. David mourned over his son day after day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom had fled and went to Geshur, and he was there three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David longed to go out to Absalom, for he was consoled that Amnon had died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab the son of Zeruiah realized that the mind of the king was on Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab sent to Tekoa and took from there a wise woman, and he said to her, “Please pretend to mourn and put on garments of mourning. You should not anoint yourself with oil, and you must act like this woman who has been mourning over the dead for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you must go to the king and speak to him according to this word.” Thus Joab put the words in her mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Tekoite woman spoke to the king, and she fell on her face to the ground and did obeisance. She said, “Help me, O king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king asked her, “What do you want?” And she said, “Truly I am a widow, and my husband is dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant had two sons, and they both fought in the open field, and there was no one to part them. One struck the other and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And look, all of the family has risen up against your servant, and they said, ‘Give up the one who struck his brother, that we may kill him in exchange for the life of his brother whom he murdered. We will also wipe out the heir,’ and so they would put out my embers which remain, by not preserving for my husband a name and a remnant on the face of the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to the woman, “Go to your house, and I myself will give the command concerning you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Tekoite woman said to the king, “On me, my lord the king, is the guilt, and on the house of my father, but the king on his throne is innocent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Whoever has spoken to you, bring him to me, and he will not touch you again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she said, “Please may the king remember Yahweh your God, to prevent the increase of blood avengers who kill, so that they not wipe out my son.” He said, “As Yahweh lives, surely not one hair shall fall from your son to the ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman said, “Please let your servant speak a word to my lord the king.” And he said, “Speak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman said, “But why have you plotted like this against the people of God? By speaking this word, he is guilty not to bring back his banished one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For we must certainly die, and we are as the waters spilled to the ground which cannot be gathered. God will not take a life but devises plans for a banished person not to be cast out from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I have come to speak this word to my lord the king, because the people made me afraid, and your servant thought, ‘I will speak to the king, perhaps the king will grant the request of his servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the king will listen, to deliver his servant from the hand of the man who seeks to destroy me and my son together from the inheritance of God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant also thought, ‘May the word of my lord the king bring rest, for as an angel of God, so is my lord the king, to sense what is good and what is bad.’ May Yahweh your God be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king answered and said to the woman, “Please do not withhold from me a thing which I am about to ask you.” The woman said, “Please let my lord the king speak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king asked, “Was the hand of Joab with you in all of this?” The woman answered and said, “As your soul lives, my lord the king, surely one cannot go to the right or to the left from all that my lord the king has spoken. Yes, your servant Joab himself commanded me, and he put all of these words in the mouth of your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In order to change the situation, your servant Joab did this thing. But my lord has wisdom, as the wisdom of an angel of God, to know all that is on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Joab, “Look, please, I will grant this thing. Go and bring back the young man Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab fell with his face to the ground and did obeisance. And he blessed the king, and he said, “Today your servant knows that I have found favor in your eyes, my lord the king, in that the king has granted the request of his servant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab got up and went to Geshur and brought Absalom to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Let him go over to his house, and he may not see my face.” So Absalom went over to his house, and did not see the face of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As far as Absalom, there was not a more handsome man in all of Israel to admire so much; from the sole of his foot up to his crown, there was no physical defect on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he shaved his head, it would happen every year, which he did because it was heavy on him, he would shave it off and weigh the hair of his head: two hundred shekels by the king’s weight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three sons were born to Absalom and one daughter, whose name was Tamar. She was a woman beautiful of appearance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom lived in Jerusalem two full years, but he did not see the face of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Absalom sent for Joab, in order that he send him to the king, but he was not willing to go to him. He sent again a second time, but he was not willing to go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he said to his servants, “Look at the tract of land of Joab next to mine, for he has barley plants there. Go, set it ablaze with fire.” So the servants of Absalom set the tract of land ablaze with fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab got up and went to Absalom, to the house, and said to him, “Why have your servants set my tract of land ablaze with fire?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom said to Joab, “Look, I have sent to you, saying, ‘Come here that I may send you to the king to say, “Why have I come from Geshur? It would be better for me if I were still there.”’ So then, let me see the face of the king; if there is guilt in me, then let him kill me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab went to the king and he told him. Then he summoned Absalom, and he came to the king, and he bowed down to him with his face to the ground before the king. Then the king kissed Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened afterward that Absalom made himself a chariot with horses and fifty men running before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom used to rise early in the morning, and he stood beside the road at the gate; anyone who had a legal dispute to bring to the king for judgment Absalom would call to him and say, “Where are you from?” And he would say, “Your servant is from one of the tribes of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom would say to him, “Look, your case is good and right, but for you there is no hearing with the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom would say, “Oh, that someone would appoint me as judge in the land, that anyone might come to me who had a legal dispute or a case, and I would give him justice.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened whenever anyone drew near to do obeisance to him, that he would stretch his hand and take hold of him and kiss him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom did like this to all of Israel who came to the king for judgment; so Absalom stole the hearts of the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened at the end of four years that Absalom said to the king, “Please let me go and pay my vow which I have made to Yahweh in Hebron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for your servant made a vow while I was staying in Geshur in Aram, saying, ‘If Yahweh will indeed let me return to Jerusalem, then I will worship Yahweh.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to him, “Go in peace.” So he got up and went to Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom sent scouts throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, “When you hear the sound of the trumpet, you shall shout ‘Absalom has become king in Hebron!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two hundred men from Jerusalem went with Absalom as invited guests, going in their innocence as they did not know anything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, the advisor of David, from his city Giloh, while he offered the sacrifices. The conspiracy grew in strength, and the people were going and increasing with Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the messenger came to David, saying, “The hearts of the men of Israel have gone after Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to all his servants who were with him in Jerusalem, “Get up and let us flee, for there will be no escape for us from Absalom! Hurry to go, otherwise he will come quickly and overtake us! And he will bring disaster on us and evil! He will attack the city with the edge of the sword!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the servants of the king said to the king, “According to all that my lord the king chooses, your servants are ready to act!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king went out with all his household following him, but the king left behind ten concubines to look after the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king went out with all the people following him, and they stopped at the last house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All his servants were passing by him: all of the Kerethites and all of the Pelethites and all of the Gittites—six hundred men who had followed him from Gath—passing before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Ittai the Gittite, “Why are you also coming with us? Return and stay with the king, for you are a foreigner; moreover, you are an exile. You are far from your place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yesterday when you came and today, I have caused you to wander by going with us. Now I am going to where I am going; return and let your brothers return. May loyal love and faithfulness be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ittai answered the king and said, “As Yahweh lives and my lord the king lives, surely in the place wherever my lord the king shall be, if for death or if for life, surely there your servant will be.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Ittai, “Go and pass over.” So Ittai the Gittite passed over and all his men and all of the little children who were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of the land was weeping with a loud voice as all the people were passing by and the king was crossing through the Wadi Kidron, and all the people were passing on the road to the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suddenly Zadok was there, and all of the Levites with him, carrying the ark of the covenant of God. They set the ark of God down, and Abiathar offered sacrifices until all the people passed out of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Zadok, “Let the ark of God return to the city. If I find favor in the eyes of Yawheh, he will let me return and let me see him in his dwelling place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if he says, ‘I take no pleasure in you,’ then I am ready. Let him do to me that which is good in his eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Zadok the priest, “Are you a seer? Return to the city in peace, with Ahimaaz your son and Jonathan the son of Abiathar, your two sons with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See, I am waiting at the fords of the wilderness until a word comes from you all to inform me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Zadok and Abiathar returned the ark of God to Jerusalem and they remained there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David was going up on the Ascent of the Olives, weeping as he went, with his head covered and going barefoot. All the people who were with him each covered their head and wept as they went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David was told, “Ahithophel was among the conspirators with Absalom.” Then David said, “Please frustrate the counsel of Ahithophel, O Yahweh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened that as David was coming up to the summit where he used to worship God, suddenly Hushai the Arkite was there to meet him. His coat was torn and dirt was on his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “If you move on with me, you will be a burden to me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but if you want to return to the city and say to Absalom, ‘I am your servant, O king. I used to be a servant of your father, but from then and now I will be your servant,’ then you can frustrate the counsel of Ahithophel for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Will not Zadok and Abiathar the priests be with you there? It shall be that all the words you hear from the house of the king you shall tell Zadok and Abiathar the priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, there with them are their two sons, Ahimaaz of Zadok and Jonathan of Abiathar. You shall send to me by means of them all the words that you hear.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hushai the friend of David came to the city as Absalom was entering Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David passed a little from beyond the summit, and suddenly Ziba the servant of Mephibosheth was there to meet him with a pair of saddled donkeys; on them were two hundred loaves of bread and a hundred raisin cakes, with a hundred summer fruits and a skin of wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Ziba, “What do you want to accomplish by bringing these?” And Ziba said, “The donkeys are for the king’s household to ride on; the bread and the summer fruit are for the young men to eat, and the wine is for the faint in the wilderness to drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said, “Where is the son of your lord?” And Ziba said to the king, “He is living in Jerusalem for he said, ‘Today the house of Israel shall return the kingdom of my father to me.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Ziba, “Look, all that was Mephibosheth’s is yours.” Ziba said, “I hereby do obeisance; may I find favor in your eyes, my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David came up to Bahurim and suddenly a man from there was coming out from the family of the house of Saul, and his name was Shimei the son of Gera. He was cursing as he came out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he threw stones at David and at all the servants of King David and at all the people and at all the mighty warriors on his right and on his left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei said while cursing him, “Go out, go out, you man of bloodshed, you man of wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh has returned on you all the blood of the household of Saul whom you have supplanted as king, and Yahweh has given the kingship into the hand of Absalom your son. Look, you are in disaster for you are a man of blood.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abishai the son of Zeruiah said to the king, “Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Please let me go over and take off his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “What do we have in common, sons of Zeruiah? If he curses because Yahweh has said to him ‘Curse David,’ who can say, “Why have you done this?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Abishai and to all his servants, “Look, my son who came out of my loins is seeking my life. Now as far as this Benjaminite, leave him alone and let him curse, for Yahweh has spoken to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Perhaps Yahweh will look in my eye and repay good for me in place of his curse this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David and his men went on the road, with Shimei going on the side of the hill beside him, cursing as he went. He threw stones beside him and threw dust in the air.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king and all of the people who were with him arrived, he was weary, so he recovered there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Absalom and all the people, the men of Israel, had come to Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator
