verses.text: When Hushai the Arkite the friend of David came to Absalom, Hushai said to Absalom, “Long live the king, long live the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom said to Hushai, “This is your loyal love with your friend? Why did you not go with your friend?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hushai said to Absalom, “No, rather, whom Yahweh and this people and all the men of Israel have chosen, to him I will be, and with him I will remain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, for whom have I served? Is it not in the presence of his son that I have served before your father? So shall I serve you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, “Give your advice. What shall we do?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Go to the concubines of your father whom he left behind to watch over the house, then all of Israel will hear that you made yourself odious to your father, and all of your followers will be motivated!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they pitched a tent for Absalom on the roof, and he went in to the concubines of his father before the eyes of all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The counsel that Ahithophel gave in those days was regarded as when a man inquired of the word of God, so all the counsel of Ahithophel was esteemed both by David and by Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Please let me choose twelve thousand men, and I will set out and pursue after David tonight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will come upon him while he is weary and weak. I will startle him, and all of the people who are with him will flee. Then I will strike down the king while he is alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will return all the people to you; when all have returned, the man whom you are seeking will be dead, but all the people will be safe.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word was right in the eyes of Absalom and in the eyes of all the elders of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom said, “Please call also for Hushai the Arkite, and let us hear what he has to say also.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hushai came to Absalom, who said to him, “Shall we do according to this word that Ahithophel has spoken? If not, then you tell us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hushai said to Absalom, “The counsel that Ahithophel gave is not good at this time.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai continued, “You know your father and his men, that they are mighty warriors and they are enraged as a bear robbed of her offspring in the field. Your father is a man of war, so he will not spend the night with the troops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now he has hidden himself in one of the caves or in one of the places. At the moment he falls on them the first time, whoever hears the report will say, ‘There has been a defeat among the people who follow after Absalom.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he is also a valiant warrior, whose heart is like the heart of the lion. He will certainly melt with fear, for all Israel knows that your father is a mighty warrior and those who are with him are valiant warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I give the advice that all of Israel from Dan to Beersheba should be completely gathered to you, as the sand which is on the seashore for abundance, with you personally going into the battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then we will come to him in one of the places where he may be found, and we shall come upon him as the dew falls on the ground. He and all the men who are with him will not survive, not even one!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even if he withdraws to a city, all Israel will bring up ropes to that city, and they will drag him away to the valley until there is not even a pebble to be found.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom and all the men of Israel said, “The advice of Hushai the Arkite is better than the advice of Ahithophel.” (Now Yahweh had ordained to frustrate the good counsel of Ahithophel in order for Yahweh to bring misery upon Absalom).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai said to Zadok and to Abiathar the priests, “Thus and so Ahithophel advised Absalom and the elders of Israel, but thus and so I have advised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, send quickly and tell David, ‘Don’t spend the night at the fords of the wilderness! Moreover, by all means cross over lest the king and all the people who are with him be swallowed up.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Jonathan and Ahimaaz were staying at En Rogel, so a servant girl used to go and tell them, then they would go and tell King David, for they were not able to be seen coming to the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a young man saw them and told Absalom, so both of them went quickly and came to the house of a man at Bahurim. Now he had a well in his courtyard, so they went down there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the woman took and spread a covering over the opening of the well; then she spread out dried grain on it, so nothing was discovered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the servants of Absalom came to the woman at the house, they said, “Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?” And she said to them, “They crossed over the brook of water.” So they searched but could not find them, so they returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they left, they came up from the well and went and told King David. They said to David, “Set out and cross over the water quickly, for thus Ahithophel has advised against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and all the people who were with him set out, and they crossed over the Jordan until morning light until there was no one missing who had not crossed over the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahithophel saw that his advice was not followed, he saddled the donkey, and he set out and went up to his house in his city. After he set his house in order, he hanged himself, and he died and was buried in the tomb of his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David had come to Mahanaim, and Absalom had crossed over the Jordan, he and all the men of Israel with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom had appointed Amasa in place of Joab over the army. Now Amasa was the son of a man whose name was Ithra the Israelite, who had married Abigail the daughter of Nahash the sister of Zeruiah, the mother of Joab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel and Absalom camped in the land of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as David had arrived in Mahanaim, Shobi the son of Nahash from Rabbah of the Ammonites and Makir the son of Ammiel from Lo Debar and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: brought beds and basins and objects of pottery, as well as wheat, barley, flour, roasted grain, beans, lentils,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: honey, curds, sheep, cheese, and cattle for David and for the people who were with him to eat. For they had thought, “The troops are hungry and weary and thirsty in the wilderness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David mustered the people who were with him, and he appointed over them commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent forth a third of the troops under the command of Joab, and a third under the command of Abishai, the brother of Joab, the son of Zeruiah, and the remaining third under the command of Ittai the Gittite. And the king said to the troops, “I, even I, will certainly go out with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the troops said, “You will not go out, for if we must flee, then they will not care about us; even if half of us die, they will not care about us, but now, you are like ten thousand of us. And so then, it is better for us that you be in the city to help.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to them, “I will do what seems good in your eyes.” So the king stood at the side of the gate while all of the troops went out by hundreds and by thousands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king ordered Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, “With respect to the young man Absalom, deal gently for me.” And all the troops heard when the king ordered all of the commanders concerning the matter of Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The army went out to the field to meet Israel, and the battle was fought in the forest of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The army of Israel was defeated there before the servants of David, and the defeat there was great on that day: twenty thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The battle there was spreading over the surface of all the land, and the forest devoured more among the army than the sword did on that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom was found in the presence of the servants of David as he was riding on the mule. The mule went under the thicket of the great oak tree, and his head was caught in the tree. He was left hanging between heaven and earth, and the mule which was under him went on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a certain man saw it, he told Joab, and he said, “Look, I saw Absalom hanging in the oak tree!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab said to the man who was telling him, “Look, if you saw, why did you not strike him down to the ground there? I would have gladly given you ten pieces of silver and a leather belt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man said to Joab, “Even if I felt the weight of a thousand pieces of silver in my palms, I would not have sent my hand against the son of the king, for in our ears the king commanded you and Abishai and Ittai, ‘Whoever you may be, protect the young man Absalom.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If I had dealt treacherously against his life, and there is not any matter hidden from the king, you would have presented yourself aloof.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said, “No longer will I wait in your presence.” Then he took three spears in his hand and thrust them into the heart of Absalom while he was still alive in the oak tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then ten of the young men who bore the weapons of Joab surrounded him and struck and killed Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab blew on the trumpet and the troops returned from pursuing after Israel, for Joab kept back the troops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took Absalom and they threw him into the large pit in the forest and raised a very great heap of stones over him. Then all of Israel fled, each to his tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now Absalom had taken and set up for himself in his lifetime a stone pillar that is in the valley of the king, because he said, “I have no son in order to remember my name,” and he called the stone pillar by his name. It is called the monument of Absalom until this day).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Ahimaaz the son of Zadok said, “Please let me run and bring the good news to the king that Yahweh has vindicated him from the hand of his enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said to him, “You will not be a man bringing good news this day! You may bring good news on another day, but today you will not be bringing good news because the king’s son is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab said to the Cushite, “Go, tell the king what you have seen”; then the Cushite bowed down to Joab and ran off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahimaaz the son of Zadok again said to Joab, “Come what may, please let me also run after the Cushite.” Joab asked, “Why are you wanting to run, my son, when for you there is no messenger’s reward?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come what may, I want to run.” He said to him, “Run,” so Ahimaaz ran on the road on the plain, and he passed the Cushite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David was sitting between the two gates, and the sentinel went up to the roof of the gate by the wall and he lifted up his eyes and watched, and look, a man was running by himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sentry called and told the king, and the king said, “If he is alone, good news is in his mouth.” He kept coming closer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the sentinel saw another man running, so the sentinel called to the gatekeeper and said, “Look, a man running alone.” The king said, “This one also is bringing good news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sentinel said, “I am seeing that the running of the first is like the running of Ahimaaz the son of Zakok.” The king said, “He is a good man; he will come, for good news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahimaaz called and said to the king, “Peace.” He bowed down to the king with his face to the ground, and he said, “May Yahweh your God be blessed, who has delivered the men who raised their hand against my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Is it peace for the young man Absalom?” Ahimaaz said, “I saw the great commotion when Joab the servant of the king sent your servant, but I do not know what it was all about.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said, “Turn aside, take your place here,” so he turned aside and waited.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suddenly the Cushite arrived and said, “May my lord the king receive the good news, for Yahweh has vindicated you today from the power of all who stood up against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to the Cushite, “Is it peace for the young man Absalom?” Then the Cushite answered, “May the enemies of my lord the king and all who rise up against you to harm you be like the young man!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king was upset, and he went up to the upper room of the gate and wept. He said as he went, “My son, Absalom, my son, my son, Absalom. If only I had died instead of you, Absalom, my son, my son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And it was told to Joab that the king was weeping and he mourned over Absalom,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so the victory turned to mourning on that day for all the army, because they had heard that day, “The king is grieving over his son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The army came secretly into the city on that day because the army was disgraced when they fled in the battle,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and because the king had covered his face and cried with a loud voice, “My son, Absalom, Absalom, my son, my son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab came to the king’s house and said, “Today you have humiliated the faces of all of your servants who have saved your life this day, and the life of your sons and your daughters, the life of your wives, and the life of your concubines,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: by loving those who hate you and hating those who love you. Indeed, you have made clear this day that you have no regard for your commanders or officers, for I have realized today that were Absalom alive, and all of us were dead, then that would have been right in your eyes!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, get up and go out and speak kindly to your servants, for I swear by Yahweh, if you do not go out, no man will lodge this night with you, and this disaster will be greater for you than any disaster that has come upon you from your childhood until now!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king got up and he sat in the gate, and they told all the army, “Look, the king is sitting in the gate.” Then all the army came before the king; whereas all of Israel had fled, each to his tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then it happened that all the people were disputing among all the tribes of Israel, saying, “The king delivered us from the hand of our enemies, and he saved us from the hand of the Philistines, but now he has fled from the land because of Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Absalom whom we anointed as king over us has died in the battle; so then, why are you taking no action to restore the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David sent to Zadok and to Abiathar the priests, saying, “Speak to the elders of Judah: ‘Why are you last to bring back the king to his house? The talk of all Israel has come to the king in his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My brothers, you are my bones and you are my flesh. Why should you be the last to bring back the king?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To Amasa you shall say: ‘Are you not my bones and my flesh? May God punish me if you are not the commander of my army before me forever, in place of Joab.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he turned the heart of all the men of Judah as one man, and they sent word to the king, “Return, you and all your servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king returned and he came to the Jordan; Judah had come to Gilgal to come to meet the king, to bring the king over the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Shimei the son of Gera, the son of the Benjaminite, who was from Bahurim quickly came down with the men of Judah to meet King David,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and a thousand men were with him from Benjamin. Too, Ziba the servant of the household of Saul and fifteen of his sons and twenty of his servants were with him, and they rushed to the Jordan before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The crossing took place to bring the household of the king over and to do good in his eyes. Then Shimei the son of Gera fell before the king when he crossed over the Jordan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he said to the king, “May not my lord hold me guilty, and may you not remember how your servant did wrong on the day that my lord the king went out from Jerusalem, by taking it to heart!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For your servant knows that I have sinned; look, I have come this day as the first of all the house of Joseph to come down to meet my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abishai the son of Zeruiah responded and said, “Because of this, should not Shimei be put to death, for he cursed the anointed one of Yahweh?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said, “What is it to me or to you, sons of Zeruiah, that you should be an adversary today? Should anyone be put to death in Israel? Do I not know today that I am king over Israel?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Shimei, “You shall not die,” and so the king swore to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Mephibosheth the son of Saul came down to meet the king; he had not taken care of his feet nor trimmed his moustache nor washed his clothes from the day the king left until the day he came back in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened that when he came to Jerusalem to meet the king, the king said to him, “Why did you not come with me, Mephibosheth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said, “My lord the king, my servant deceived me, for your servant had said, ‘Let me saddle the donkey that I may ride on her and go with the king,’ for your servant is lame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he slandered against your servant to my lord the king. My lord the king is like the angel of God; do as you see fit..”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For there was no one in all the house of my father who were not doomed to death before my lord the king, but you set your servant among those who eat at your table. Do I have any righteousness any longer except to cry out to the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to him, “Why should you speak any more about the matter? I have decided: you and Ziba shall divide the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Mephibosheth said to the king, “Let him take the whole thing, since my lord the king has come safely to his house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Barzillai the Gileadite came down from Rogelim and crossed with the king over the Jordan to escort him through the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Barzillai was very old, eighty years old. Now he had provided the king with food while he was staying at Mahanaim, for he was a very wealthy man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Barzillai, “You cross over with me, and I will provide for you to dwell with me in Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Barzillai said to the king, “What are the days of the years of my life, that I should go with the king to Jerusalem?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am eighty years old today. Can I discern between good and bad? Or can your servant taste what I eat or what I drink? Or can I still hear the voice of singing men and women? Why should your servant be a burden any longer to my lord the king?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant shall go over the Jordan with the king a little way, but why should the king recompense me with this reward?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please let your servant return, and let me die in my city in the tomb of my father and my mother. Here is your servant Kimham; let him cross over with my lord the king, and do for him that which is good in your eyes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Let Kimham go over with me, and I will do for him the good in your eyes, and all that you desire of me I will do for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people crossed over the Jordan, and the king crossed and kissed Barzillai and blessed him; then he returned to his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king went over to Gilgal, and Kimham went over with him. All the people of Judah went over with the king, and half of the people of Israel too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suddenly, all the men of Israel were coming to the king. They said to the king, “Why have our brothers the men of Judah stolen away and brought the king and his household over the Jordan, with all the men of David?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, “Because the king is my close relative! Why are you this angry over this matter? Have we by any means eaten anything from the king? Did we take by any means anything that was not ours?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of Israel answered the men of Judah and said, “I have ten times as much in the king, moreover in David I have more than you. Why did you treat me with contempt by not giving me first chance to bring back my king?” But the words of the men of Judah were fiercer than the word of the men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a man of wickedness was found there whose name was Sheba the son of Bichri, a Benjaminite. He blew the horn and said, “There is no share for us in David, and there is no inheritance for us in the son of Jesse; each to his tents, O Israel!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the men of Israel went up from following after David, following instead after Sheba the son of Bicri, but the men of Judah stuck to their king from the Jordan up to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went up to his house in Jerusalem, then the king took the ten concubines whom he had left to look after the house, and he put them under confinement. However, he provided for them, but he did not sleep with them. So they were confined until the day of their death, like a lifetime of widowhood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Amasa, “Summon for me the men of Judah within three days, and be here yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amasa went to summon Judah, but he tarried more than the appointed time which he had set for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Abishai, “Now Sheba the son of Bicri will do us more harm than Absalom. You take the servants of your lord and pursue after him, lest he find fortified cities for himself and escape from us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the men of Joab, the Kerethites and the Pelethites, and all the mighty warriors went out after him; they went out from Jerusalem to pursue after Sheba the son of Bicri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were near the big rock that is in Gibeon, and Amasa came before them. Joab was dressed in his military clothing, with a utility belt on him and a sword strapped to his waist in its scabbard. Now he went out, and it fell out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab said to Amasa, “Is it peace, O you my brother?” Then the right hand of Joab took hold of the beard of Amasa as if to kiss him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Amasa was not on his guard against the sword that was in Joab’s hand, and he struck him with it into the stomach, and his entrails poured out to the ground. He did not strike him again, and he died. Then Joab and Abishai his brother pursued after Sheba the son of Bicri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A young man stood over him, from the young men of Joab, and he said, “Whoever takes delight in Joab and whoever is for David, follow after Joab.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Amasa was wallowing in the blood in the middle of the highway; when the man saw that all the people stood there, he turned Amasa over from the highway into the field, and he threw a garment over him because he had seen that all who had come by him had stopped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he was removed from the highway, all the men passed by after Joab to pursue after Sheba the son of Bicri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (He had passed through all the tribes of Israel to Abel and Beth Maacah; now all of the Berites had been treated badly, so they also followed after him.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they came and besieged him in Abel Beth Maacah. They threw up a siege ramp against the city, and they stood against the ramparts. And all the army who were with Joab were battering to cause the wall to fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a wise woman from the city called out, “Listen, listen! Please speak to Joab to come near here so that I may speak to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he came near to her, and the woman asked, “Are you Joab?” And he said, “I am.” Then she said to him, “Listen to the words of your servant.” He said, “I am listening.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she said, “In former times, they would always say, ‘By all means, let them inquire in Abel,’ and so they settled things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am one of the faithful representatives of Israel. You are seeking to destroy a city and a mother in Israel. Why do you want to swallow the inheritance of Yahweh?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab answered and said, “Far be it, far be it from me that I should swallow or I should destroy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is not the matter. But a man from the mountains of Ephraim, whose name is Sheba the son Bicri, has lifted up his hand against the king, against David. Give only him to us, and I will depart from the city.” The woman said to Joab, “Look, his head is being thrown down to you over the wall.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman went to all of the people with her wise plan, so they cut off the head of Sheba the son of Bicri and threw it to Joab. Then he blew the horn and dispersed from the city, each to his tent. Then Joab returned to Jerusalem to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joab was over all the army of Israel and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the Carites and over the Pelethites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adoram was over the forced labor, and Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was the recorder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shiya was secretary, and Zadok and Abiathar were priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also Ira the Jairite was priest for David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a famine in the days of David for three years, year after year. And David inquired of Yahweh, and Yahweh said, “The bloodguilt is on Saul and on his household, because he killed the Gibeonites.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king called the Gibeonites and spoke to them. Now the Gibeonites were not from the Israelites; they were from the remainder of the Amorites. Now the Israelites had sworn to them, but Saul tried to wipe them out in his zeal for the Israelites and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David asked the Gibeonites, “What can I do for you, and with what can I make amends that you may bless the inheritance of Yahweh?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Gibeonites said to him, “It is not a matter for us of silver or gold with Saul or with his household. It is not for us to put to death anyone in Israel.” He asked, “What are you saying that I should do for you all?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said to the king, “The man who consumed us and who plotted against us so that we were destroyed from existing in all of the territory of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: let seven men from his sons be given over to us, and we will execute them before Yahweh in Gibeah of Saul, the chosen one of Yahweh.” Then the king said, “I will give them over.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king spared Mephibosheth the son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, because of the sworn oath of Yahweh which was between them, between David and Jonathan the son of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king took two of the sons of Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, whom she bore to Saul, namely Armoni and Mephibosheth, and five of the sons of Michal the daughter of Saul whom she had borne to Adriel the son of Barzillai the Meholathite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He gave them into the hands of the Gibeonites, and they executed them on the mountain in the presence of Yahweh, and the seven fell together. Now they were put to death in the days of the harvest, at the beginning of the harvest of barley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rizpah the daughter of Aiah took the sackcloth, and she spread it for herself on the rock at the beginning of the harvest until water gushed forth on them from heaven, but she did not allow the birds of heaven to rest on them by day nor the animals of the field by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was told about what Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, the concubine of Saul, had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David left and took the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son from the rulers of Jabesh Gilead, who had stolen them from the public square of Beth Shan, where the Philistines hung them when the Philistines killed Saul on Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought up the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son from there, and they gathered the bones of the executed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they buried the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son in the land of Benjamin at Zela, in the tomb of Kish his father. They did all that the king had commanded, and afterward God was entreated for the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war again for the Philistines with Israel, and David and his servants with him went down, and they fought the Philistines, and David grew weary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Yishbi in Nob, who was among the descendents of Raphah (now the weight of his spearhead was three hundredweight of bronze, and he was newly armed), said that he would kill David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abishai the son of Zeruiah helped him, and he attacked the Philistine and killed him. Then the men of David swore to him, saying, “You shall not go out with us any longer to the battle, so that you do not quench the lamp of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened afterward that there was again battle at Gob with the Philistines. Then Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Saph who was among the descendants of the Raphah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was again a battle with the Philistines at Gob. And Elhanan the son of Jaare-Oregim, the Bethlehemite, killed Goliath the Gittite, the shaft of whose spear was like the beam of a weaver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once again there was battle at Gath, and there was a man of great size. The fingers of his hand and the toes of his feet were six and six, twenty-four in number. He was also born to the Raphah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He taunted Israel but Jonathan the son of Shimei, the brother of David, killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These four were born for the Raphah in Gath, and they fell by the hand of David and by the hand of his servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David spoke to Yahweh the words of this song, on the day Yahweh delivered him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And he said:
    “Yahweh is my rock, my fortress, and my deliverer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I take refuge in God, my rock, my shield, and the strength of my salvation.
    My stronghold and my refuge, O my savior, you will save me from violence!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I call upon Yahweh who is praiseworthy,
    and I am saved from those who hate me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the breaker waves of death engulfed me;
    the currents of chaos overwhelmed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The ropes of Sheol entangled me;
    the snares of death confronted me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In my distress I called upon Yahweh, and to my God I called.
    He heard my voice from his temple,
    and my cry for help was to his ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth heaved and shook,
    the foundations of heaven trembled and heaved
    because he was angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Smoke went up from his nostrils and fire from his mouth.
    Burning coals devoured, they burned from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He bowed the heavens and came down;
    a very thick cloud was under his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He rode upon a cherub and flew;
    he was seen on the wings of the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He put darkness as a canopy all around him,
    a collection of thick rain clouds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From the brightness before him
    flamed burning coals of fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh thundered from heaven,
    and the Most High uttered his voice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He sent arrows and he scattered them,
    lightning, and he directed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the channels of water of the sea were exposed,
    the foundations of the world,
    at the rebuke of Yawheh,
    from the blast of the breath of his nostrils.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He sent from a high position and took me;
    he drew me from mighty waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He delivered me from my strong enemies,
    from those who hate me, for they were mightier than I.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They approached me on the day of my disaster,
    but Yahweh was my support.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He brought me out to a spacious place.
    He delivered me because he delighted in me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh rewarded me according to my righteousness,
    according to the cleanness of my hands he recompensed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For I have kept the ways of Yahweh;
    I have not acted wickedly against my God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For all of his ordinances were before me,
    and I did not turn aside from his statutes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I was blameless before him,
    and I kept myself from my iniquity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh has recompensed me according to my righteousness,
    according to my cleanness before his eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With the loyal, you act as loyal,
    and with the blameless, you show yourself blameless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With the pure, you show yourself pure,
    but with the crooked, you appear as a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Humble people you will deliver,
    but your eyes are on the haughty, whom you bring down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For you, O Yahweh are my lamp,
    and Yahweh lightens my darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For by you I can run a raid;
    by my God I can leap over a wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
For who is God apart from Yahweh?
    And who is a rock apart from our God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God is my strong refuge,
    he has fully opened my way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He makes my feet like a doe deer,
    and on my high places he has set me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He trains my hands for the war,
    so that my arms can bend a bow of bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have given me the shield of your salvation;
    your willingness to help has made me great.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have broadened my steps beneath me;
    my ankles have not wobbled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I pursued those who hate me, and I destroyed them.
    I did not turn back until finishing them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I wiped them out and I smashed them;
    they did not get up; they fell under my feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have girded me with physical strength for the battle;
    you caused those who rose up against me to kneel under me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My enemies you cause to retreat from me;
    I destroy those who hate me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They looked out, but there was no deliverer,
    even to Yahweh, but he did not answer them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I beat them fine, like the dust of the earth;
    like the mire of the streets, I crushed them, I stamped them down.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Children of a foreign land came cringing to me;
    when they heard of me, they became obedient to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Children of a foreign land lost heart
    and came trembling from their strongholds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh lives! Blessed be my rock!
    May God, the rock of my salvation, be exalted!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God does vengeance for me,
    bringing down peoples under me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He brings me out from my enemies,
    and from those who rose up against me you lift me up,
    and from men of violence you rescue me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore I will extol you, Yahweh, among the nations!
    I will sing praises to your name!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He makes great salvation for his king
    and shows loyal love to his anointed one, David
    and to his descendants forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the last words of David, the declaration of David the son of Jesse, and the declaration of the man exalted by the Most High, the anointed one of the God of Jacob and the darling of the songs of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The spirit of Yahweh speaks through me, and his word is upon my tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The God of Israel said to me, the rock of Israel has spoken; ‘He who rules over mankind rules righteously, in the fear of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Like the light of the morning when the sun rises, shining with no clouds, bringing vegetation from the earth apart from rain.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet not so is my house with God, for he made an everlasting covenant for me, arranging everything. He has secured all my deliverance, and all my desire he will cause to happen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But evil persons are like thorns cast aside; all of them, because they cannot be picked up in the hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if a man wants to touch them, he must use an iron instrument or the shaft of a spear; then they are consumed entirely with fire on the spot.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of the mighty warriors who were David’s: Josheb-Basshebeth a Tahkemonite was chief of three officers; first Adino, whose spear was against eight hundred slain on one occurrence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next to him Eleazar, the son of Dodo the son of an Ahohite, was among the three mighty warriors with David when they defied the Philistines and they gathered there for the battle and the men of Israel withdrew.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stood up and struck down the Philistines until his hand grew tired and his hand clung to the sword, and Yahweh brought about a great victory on that day. Then the army returned back to him only for stripping the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next to him was Shamma, the son of Agee the Hararite. When the Philistines assembled at Lehi, a plot of the field was there filled with lentils, and the army fled there from the presence of the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he took a stand in the middle of the plot of land and defended it. He killed the Philistines, and Yahweh brought about a great victory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then three of the thirty leaders went down and came to David at the time of the harvest to the cave of Adullam, while a group of the Philistines were camping in the valley of the Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now at that time, David was in the stronghold, and a garrison of the Philistines was in Bethlehem at that same time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said longingly, “Oh that someone would bring me a drink of water from the well of Bethlehem that is at the gate.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So three of the mighty warriors broke into the camp of the Philistines, and they drew water from the well of Bethlehem that was at the gate, and they carried it and brought it to David. But he was not willing to drink it, but poured it out to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Far be it from me before Yahweh that I should do this. Is this not the blood of the men who went at the risk of their lives?” So he was not willing to drink it. These things the three mighty warriors did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Abishai the brother of Joab the son of Zeruiah was himself the leader of the thirty. He was wielding his spear against three hundred slain and gained a name among the thirty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Among the thirty, is it not that he was honored and became a commander for them? But he did not come up to the three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, the son of Ish-Hai, was a great man of deeds from Kabzeel. He struck down two sons of Ariel of Moab, and he went down and killed a lion in the middle of a pit on a snowy day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also killed a good-looking Egyptian man, in whose hand was a spear. He went down against him with the staff and snatched the spear from the hand of the Egyptian and killed him with his spear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These things Benaiah the son of Jehoiada did and gained a name for himself among the three mighty warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was honored more than the thirty, but he did not come up to the three. David appointed him in charge of his bodyguard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Among the thirty were Asahel the brother of Joab, Elhanan the son of Dodo of Bethlehem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shammah the Harodite, Elika the Harodite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Helez the Paltite, Ira the son of Ikkesh the Tekoite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abiezer the Anathothite, Mebunnai the Hushathite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Heleb the son of Baanah the Netophathite, Ittai the son of Ribai from Gibeah of the sons of Benjamin,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah the Pirathonite, Hiddai from the wadis of Gaash,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abi-Albon the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Barhumite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eliahba the Shaalbonite, the sons of Jashen, Jonathan
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the son of Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam the son of Sharar the Ararite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eliphelet the son of Ahasbai the son of the Maacathite, Eliam the son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezro the Carmelite, Paarai the Arbite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Igal the son of Nathan from Zobah, Bani the Gadite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, the carriers of the weapons of Joab the son of Zeruiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uriah the Hittite; in all, thirty-seven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again Yahweh was angry with Israel, and he incited David against them, saying, “Go count Israel and Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Joab, the commander of the army who was with him: “Please go about through all the tribes of Israel from Dan to Beersheba, and count the people that I may know the number of the people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab said to the king, “May Yahweh your God increase the people a hundred times what they are as the eyes of my lord the king are seeing. But my lord the king, why does he desire this thing?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the word of the king prevailed over Joab and over the commanders of the army, so Joab and the commanders of the army went out from before the king to count the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They crossed over the Jordan and camped at Aroer to the south of the city, which was in the middle of the wadi of Gad, and up to Jazer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they went to Gilead and to the land of Tahtim Hodshi. They came to Dan Jaan and around to Sidon
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and came to the fortress of Tyre and all the cities of the Hivites and the Canaanites. Then they went out to the Negev of Judah at Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went about through all the land, and they came to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab gave the number of the counting of the people to the king. Israel was eight hundred thousand valiant warriors wielding the sword, and the men of Judah were five hundred thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The heart of David struck him after he had counted the people, and David said to Yahweh, “I have sinned greatly in what I have done! So then, O Yahweh, please forgive the guilt of your servant because I have acted very foolishly.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David got up in the morning, the word of Yahweh came to Gad the prophet, the seer of David, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and speak to David, ‘Thus says Yahweh, three things I am laying on you; choose for yourself one of them and I will do it to you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Gad came to David, and he told him and said to him, “Shall seven years of famine in the land come to you? Or three months of your fleeing from your enemies while he is pursuing you? Or should there be three days of pestilence in your land? Now consider and decide what I must return to the one who sent me a word.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Gad, “I am greatly distressed. Please let us fall into the hand of Yahweh, because he is great in his compassion; but into the hand of man don’t let me fall.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Yahweh sent a plague into Israel from the morning until the agreed time, and from the people from Dan to Beersheba, seventy thousand men died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the angel stretched out his hand to destroy Jerusalem, Yahweh regretted about the evil, and he said to the angel who brought destruction among the people, “Enough, now relax your hand.” Now the angel of Yahweh was at the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David spoke to Yahweh when he saw the angel destroying among the people, and he said, “Look, I have sinned and I have done wrong, but these sheep, what did they do? Please let your hand be against me and against the house of my father.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Gad came to David on that same day and said to him, “Go up and erect an altar to Yahweh at the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went up according to the word of Gad, as Yahweh had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Araunah looked down and saw the king and his servants coming over to him, so Araunah went out and bowed down before the king with his face to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Araunah said, “Why has my lord the king come to his servant?” David said, “To buy from you the threshing floor, to build an altar to Yahweh who brought a halt to the plague on the people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Araunah said to David, “Let my lord the king take and offer what is good in his eyes. Look, here are the cattle for the burnt offering and the threshing sledge and the yokes of the oxen for the firewood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of this Araunah hereby gives to the king.” Then Araunah said to the king, “May Yahweh your God respond favorably for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Araunah, “No, but I will certainly buy it from you for a price; I don’t want to offer to Yahweh my God burnt offerings that cost me nothing.” So David bought the threshing floor and the cattle for fifty shekels of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David built an altar to Yahweh there, and he offered burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. Then Yahweh responded to his prayer for the land and brought the plague to a halt from upon Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator
